coredata.dc:title: X-ray absorption near edge structures (xanes) of Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 Co shift catalysts
coredata.dc:creator: Vlaic, G.
Bart, J.C.J.
Cavigiolo, W.
Mobilo, S.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
X-ray absorption near edge structures (XANES) of some Cu/ZnO/Al2O3CO shift catalysts have been measured at high resolution using synchrotron radiation, and compared to reference compounds Prior to reduction. CuO and ZnO are present, after reduction ZnO and highly dispersed Cu, no indication was found for Cu2O or the presence of spinels. The results are qualitatively confirmed by preliminary analysis of EXAFS spectra.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 76 number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 15 December 1980 X-RAY ABSORPTION NEAR EDGE STRUCTURES (XANES) OF Cu/ZnO/Al203 CO SHIFT CATALYSTS G VLAIC, J C.J BART, W. CAVIGIOLO Istltttio G Donegani S p A , Novara. Italy and S. MOBILIO Laboralori Nazionah di Frascait MFf^, Gruppo PULS Frascali, Italy Recei\ed 18 June 1980, in final form 17 September 1980 X-ray absorption near edge structures (XANES; of some Cu/ZoO/AM^ CO shift catalysts have been measured at high resolution using synchrotron radiation, and compared to reference compounds Prior to reduction. CuO and ZnO are present, after reduction ZnO and highly dispersed Cu, no indication was found for Cu;0 or the presence of spinels The results are qualitatively confirmed b> preliminary analysis of EXAFS spectra 1. Introduction Conversion of CO at low temperature is commonly performed industrially with catalysts such as Cu/ZnO/Al203 [1-3] The chemical and physical microstructure of the single phases and the role of the various components of the system have recently extensively been studied by a variety of experimental techniques [4-7]. However, the usual degree of dis- persion of the active phase on the support (typically =100 A for co-precipitated catalysts after activation by reduction) is often an obstacle to many of the traditional methods of structural investigation Also, incipient formation of spinel type structures (CuAIzO.!, ZnAIaO-i, y-AlsOs) causes problems m their detection As already reported [8, 9] the study of extended X-ray absorption spectra (EXAFS) allows us to determine with high accuracy the local structural parameters of the constituent atoms, such as the coordination number, the interatomic distances, thermal and/or structural disorder, and therefore appears as a promising way of resolving structural problems relating to less ordered systems. Moreover, it has recently been pointed out that high-resolution studies within a few eV of a core level threshold may be used to derive chemical and physical information, such as the charge density and local environment of the absorbing atom [10] In recent years these new experimental techniques, EXAFS and XANES, have received great impetus through access to electron storage rings as intense continuous X-ray sources. An experimental approach to determine the local structure of an atom in a complex system is to compare the near-edge absorption spectrum of the selected atom with that of the same atom in reference compounds of known characteristics [II, 12]. We have used this approach to study the nature of Cu and Zn in various fresh and reduced Cu/ZnO/Al;;C>3 catalysts in order to gain insight into the structural features of these CO shift catalysts. 2. Experimental 21. Materials CuaO, CuO and ZnO were R.P.C. Erba products; Cu and Zn were available as sheets (20 x 10 x 0.004 mm) from Goodfellow Metals, Ltd. ZnA^O.* 453 Volume 76. number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 15 December 1980 was prepared by hot precipitation of ZntNOa) 6H20 and A1(NC>3)3 9H:>0 in aqueous solution with sodium carbonate After washing and drying at 110 C for 8 h the sample was calcined at 1200 C for 8 h There are numerous routes to Cu/ZnO/AIaC^ catalysts and various preparations were examined in our XANES characterization study Catalysts were either commercially available products or samples prepared by hot precipitation of nitrates in aqueous solution with sodium carbonate. Reduction of the catalysts was carried out with a H^/N; fluv {p=\ aim, space velocity = 50000 h~1) in a micronow apparatus for about 14 h at temperatures ranging from 25 to 230 C 2 2. Physico-cfiemical characterisation X-ray diffraction (XRD) powder spectra of fresh catalyst samples were recorded with a Philips PW 1050/70 powder diffractometer using Cu Ka (A = 1.5418 A) radiation for structure and phase analysis Crystallite sizes were determined by cal- culations employing Scherrer's equation [13] Powder samples for XANES experiments were mi\ed with boron nitride used as a diluent and mounted in a metallic frame in the form of pressed tablets. The absorption coefficient p. was calculated using the formula p. = -(l/v) In W/o)i where v is the sample thickness The loading ranged from 10 to 15 mg/cirr and'was chosen in agreement with fiv== 1 so as to optimize the contrast at the high-absorption side of the Cu K edge Catalysts reduced in the apparatus described above were transferred under He atmosphere to a steel sample holder provided with X-ray transparent mylar windows and were kept in an inert atmosphere throughout the measurements XANE5 experiments were performed ai the Syn- chrotron Radiation Facility "PULS" (progetto utilizzazione luce di sincrotrone) at the National Laboratories, Frascati, Italy, using the X-ray beam. The experimental apparatus is described in detail elsewhere [14]. The X rays emitted by the ADONE storage ring facility at 1 5 GeV with a typical current of 50 mA were monochromatized by a channel-cut Si (220) Single crystal and monitored (a^/o) in a first transmission ion chamber filled with a He/Nz mix- lure. After passing through the sample, the beam intensity I was measured by a second, total absorp- tion ionization chamber filled with a Nz/Ar mixture The apparatus was operated under control of a PDP 11/03 minicomputer which drives the shafts of the monochromator and records the digitized currents fo and / of the ionization chambers for subsequent data analysis In the experiments the typical photon flux was ==5 x 10s photons/s per eV of bandwidth for the energy ranges used (8500-10500 eV) with an energy resolution Af/fss 10"^ at 7 keV. The high intensity and the stability of the monochromatic X-ray beam lead to a high signal-to-noise ratio and consequently allow high-resolution X-ray absorption spectroscopy in comparison to conventional X-ray sources Cali- bration of the energy scale was performed by attri- bution of literature values [15] to the maxima in the first-derii.ative XANES spectra of metallic Cu and Zn ( 2: (Cu) = 8980 3 eV, E^, (Zn = 9660 7 eV) The chemical shifts of the reference compounds (CuO, Cu^O, ZnO and ZnAIzO^} and the catalysts, which are characteristic of the charge densities of Cu and Zn, were taken to correspond to the energy difference between the position of the first-derivative XANES spectrum and the above values for the ele- ments in the metallic state- All spectra were taken at room temperature at 0 2eV intervals over a range of ^lOOeV extending up to 60 eV abo\e the K thresholds of Cu and Zn Data processing was carried out on a Univac 1100/20 computer using a Tektromx model 4015/1 graphics terminal according to the procedure of Lytle et al. [8] with a program set which had been locally modified and expanded with smoothing and other graphical facilities of the Department of Automation of the G Donegam Institute- 3. Results XRD line broadening indicated already high dis- persion and considerable amounts of amorphous phases in our preparations Table 1 reports the phase distribution of the various catalyst samples. In fresh catalysts, crystallite sizes of ZnO(llO) and CuO(lll) range from 65 to 115 A- No conclusive evidence was found for compound formation among the components in the oxidized state but it should be stressed that the XRD diagrams are not easily mterpretable. 454 Volume 76 number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 15 December 1980 Table 1 Cu/ZnO/AI;03 catalysts investigated Sample Composition; number (vMt o) Phase analysis Crystallite size (A) Ref CuOdin ZnOlllO) 1 24 47 15 CuO, ZnO 66 94 this i^ork 2 29 45 12 CuO, ZnO. other " - [I6J 3 27 52 12 CuO. ZnO. other h' .S7 115 [17] .1 26 67 0 CuO, ZnO 1(13 96 this ^ork CuO ZnO AI::O.) remainder consists of volatiles (H:>0, CO.; etc 1 t" Small amounts X-ray Cu and Zn K-edge photoabsorption spectra (XANES) of fresh and reduced Cu/ZnO/AhO} catalysts are g!'.en in figs- 1 I comparison with reference compounds. In figs 1-4 the ordinate fiv (in arbitrary units) is given by In {loll}, where /u and / are the incident and transmitted beam intensities, respectively Considerable structure near the K edge is observed, followed by a rapidly damped oscillatory modulation of the absorption at higher photon energies (EXAFS) Numerical results, taken from the ma\ima of the derivative spectra, are listed in table 2 Reported energy \alues for the absorption edges are on a relative rather than absolute scale due 10 inherent difficulties in defining the position of the 8965 8375 8985 8995 9005 9015 9025 9035 90A5 E(eV) Fig I X-ray absorption spectra near the Cu K edge of fresh Cu/ZnO/Ah03 catalysts l l (for numbering scheme see tables 1 and 2) and CuO (curve 5) absorption edge and to determination of the effective d spacing of the monochromaior Nevertheless the numerical values reported are well suited to compare chemical shifts. 4. Discussion The use of the analysis of the X-ray absorption near-edge structures to obtain information about the chemical state of an element is still in its infancy. It has been shown [11] that details of unknown local Fig 2 X-ray absorption spectra near the Cu K edge of reduced Cu/ZnO/AI;03 catalysts (curves 1-4), metallic Cu (curve 5) and Cu;0 (curve 6) 455 Volume 76. number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS IS December 1980 9Et.5 9655 S665 967S 9685 9695 3706 9715 9725 9T35 9-^5 E(eV) Fig 3 X-ray absorption spectra near the Zn K edge of fresh Cu/ZnOy-M^Oa catalysis (cunes 1 *>, ZnO (curie 5) ZnAl204 (CUP'S 6) and metallic Zn (cun.e 7) 96^.5 9 55 9665 S675 9685 S6S5 9'705 9715 9725 9735 97.5 EleV) Fig 4 X-ray absorption spectra near the Zn K edge of reduced Cu/ZnO/Al.;03 catalysis (cun.es 1-4), ZnO (curve 5). ZnAIzO^ (curve 6) and metallic Zn (curve 7) (first-shell) structures can be extracted from high- resolution near-edge spectra, as recorded by the use of synchrotron radiation In this study we have used an empirical approach to determine the local struc- ture of metal atoms in Cu/ZnO/AbO} catalysts by means of XANES spectra Although the simple osides CuO and ZnO are not isornorphous, the cations in both structures are octa- hedrally coordinated The X-ray absorption spectra of the fresh Cu/ZnO/AlaOa catalyst samples (figs 1 and 3) show essentially similar features as those of the free oxides, as also expressed by the chemical shifts This shows that the electronic charge state of the metal in the fresh catalyst and its first coordina- tion sphere are similar to those in CuO and ZnO. The chemical shift of all samples (referred to metallic zinc) amounts to 3.7 0 2 eV (table 2), in accordance with the value; measured for ZnO. In the case ot copper, the chemical shift of CuO and the catalyst samples amounts to 4.7 02 eV, in satisfactory agreement with XPS and EXAFS measurements (4 4(5) [18], 3.6(5) [9]), 3.87(45) eV [19]), especially if we take into account the lower spectral resolution in previous work and differences in evaluation of the edge position. The ^(k) EXAFS signal of Cu in the fresh catalyst 1, which is similar to that of CuO (fig. 5), confirms that the coordination sphere of the cation is constituted of oxygens. We have been unable to account for the observed difference in chemical shift for the fresh and reduced catalyst 3, especially as the shape of the absorption edge does not vary with respect to the other spectra. A detailed EXAFS study might throw more light on this problem- In the past, the formation of spinel structures in Cu/ZnO/AlzOa catalysts has been advanced [7, 16] 456 Volume 76, number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 15 December 1980 Table 2 K-absorption edge values and energy shifts (eV) for some Cu/ZnO/AliCV} catalysts and selected reference compounds Sample " K(Cu) b) A K(CU) " , K(Zn)1" ^E^W" Clj 8980-3(1) +00(ref) CuO 8985.0(1) +4 7(2) - - Cu^O 89802(1) -0 1(2) - - Zn - - 96607(1) +0 0(ref ZnO - - 96644(1) +37(2) ZnAlz04 - - 96637(1) +3 0(2) cat I 89850(1) +4 7(2) 96644(1) +3 7(2) cat 2 8985 0(1) +4 7(2) 9664 4(1) +3 7(2) cat 3 8983 8(1) +3 5(2) 96644(1) +3 7(2) cat 4 89850(1) +4 7(2) 96644(1) +3 7(2) cat 1R 8980 3(1) -r0 0(2) 96644(1) +3-7(2) cat 2R 89803(1) ---00(2) 96644(1) +3 7(2) cai 3R 8981 0(1) +0 7(2) 9664 8(1) +4 1(2) cat 4R 89850(1) +4 7(2) 96644(1) +3 7(2) :" Catalyst numbering system as in table 1, R means reduced b' Position of the K-absorption edge " Energy shift, K- "K(Cu ) ' Energy shift, E^-E^Zn") Taking into account the reported values of K-edge shifts for CuAlzOL* (5 9(5) [9] and 7.95(45) eV [20]) the presence of this spinel is unlikely in our samples. Similarly, our experimental data do not lend support for the presence of crystalline ZnAlaO^ (figs. 3 and 4, table 2). Amongst others, this is also clearly seen if we compare the EXAFS signals for the fresh and reduced catalyst 1 with those of ZnO and ZnAl-.Oli (fig. 6) The K-edge XANES photoabsorption spectra of Zn of reduced catalysts (fig 4 and table 2) are consistent with the hypothesis that zinc is present as 35 105 115 IZ5 h( ') Fig 5 EXAFS oscillations of Cu in the fresh Cu/ZnO/AI^O, catalyst 1 (curve I) and CuO (curve 2) Zn2^ rather than Zn . The fact that reduction does not affect zinc is also confirmed by EXAFS analysis of the Zn absorption edge of the fresh and reduced catalyst 1 (fig. 6). Chemical shifts of Cu in reduced Cu/ZnO/AIzO^ samples 1R, 2R and 3R (table 2) suggest that cupric ions are reduced to cuprous ions under formation of CuzO or that one obtains a highly dispersed state of zero-valent copper atoms differing from copper atoms in bulk metallic copper. The latter hypothesis is supported by the antiphase features of the XANES spectra of CuzO and reduced catalysts at the high- energy side of the Cu K-absorption edge. As the details of the XANES spectra differ from those of bulk Cu we interpret our results as indicating a copper phase consisting of very small crystallites. The presence of Cu as the scattering element in the first and probably in the second shell is confirmed by the EXAFS signal of the reduced catalyst 1 (fig. 7), which is in good accord with that of metallic Cu both in terms of identically spaced wiggles in the sinusoidal function \(k) as well as in the reproduction of the fine structure. The decreased signal intensity with respect to metallic copper indicates a variation of the scattering amplitude, probably resulting from a 457 Volume 76, number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 15 December 1980 Fig. 6. EXAFS oscillations of Zn in the fresh (curve 1) and reduced (curve 2) Cu/ZnO/AlaO-i catalyst !, ZnO (curve 3), ZnAl;04 (curve 4) and metallic Zn (curve 5) decrease in coordination number. This points to reduced dimensions of the metallic dusters, i.e. to higher dispersion. This may be considered to be in line with a fine copper dispersion in contact with zinc oxide [4]. A detailed EXAFS investigation will be reported in a later paper. Fig. 7. EXAFS oscillations of Cu in the reduced Cu/ZnO/ AliOl catalyst 1 (curve li and metallic Cu (curve 2>, 5. Conclusions One of the objectives of this work was to test the applicability of the XANES technique to catalytic problems. The results demonstrate this applicability in that the gross features of local structure and chemical bonding in unknown Cu/ZnO/AlzOi catalyst samples were determined by an empirical approach, consisting in comparing XANES spectra of the catalysts with reference compounds of known local structure. In particular, our results indicate that in reduced catalysts, CuO rather than ZnO is reduced to the metallic state [4,21], in good agreement with the higher (thermodynamic) stability of ZnO towards reduction. Obvious limitations of XANES are related to analysis of well-defined systems containing various forms of the absorbing atom. In the present case this concerns information relating to dissolution of CuO in ZnO [6, 22], the formation of CuzO-ZnO solid solutions [23] or interactions leading to the formation in the fresh catalyst of minor amounts of CuAl;04 or Cu^/ZnAl^, as detected by ESR spectroscopy [7]. Similarly, minor features, such as the presence of a' brass in reduced and aged catalysts [21], are not easily detectable. Also, the method is not expected to detect the small fraction of dissolved Cu' species in a zinc oxide phase which has been described as being the active phase [4,6]. ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: X-ray absorption near edge structures (XANES) of some Cu/ZnO/Al2O3CO shift catalysts have been measured at high resolution using synchrotron radiation, and compared to reference compounds Prior to reduction. CuO and ZnO are present, after reduction ZnO and highly dispersed Cu, no indication was found for Cu2O or the presence of spinels. The results are qualitatively confirmed by preliminary analysis of EXAFS spectra.
